name: Havana Capitol
description: Havana is the capital and largest city of Cuba, known for its iconic Capitol building, Spanish colonial architecture, and rich cultural heritage. The city combines traditional Cuban culture with historic charm, featuring the historic Old Havana, Malecón waterfront, and vibrant music scene.

name: Tegucigalpa Cathedral Basilica
description: Tegucigalpa is the capital city of Honduras, known for its beautiful Cathedral Basilica - a magnificent colonial-era cathedral that serves as the spiritual heart of the city. The cathedral represents the rich religious heritage and colonial architecture of Honduras, standing as an iconic landmark in the historic center of Tegucigalpa.

name: Divino Salvador del Mundo
description: San Salvador is the capital and largest city of El Salvador, home to the iconic Divino Salvador del Mundo monument - a towering statue of Jesus Christ standing atop the world. This beloved monument, depicting Christ as the Divine Savior of the World, is the national symbol of El Salvador and represents the deep Catholic faith and national identity of the Salvadoran people.

name: Cahal Pech Maya Ruins
description: San Ignacio is a vibrant town in western Belize, gateway to the ancient Cahal Pech Maya ruins. Perched on a hilltop overlooking the town, Cahal Pech was once a royal acropolis-palace of an elite Maya family during the Classic Period. The archaeological site features plazas, temples, and residential structures that offer a glimpse into the sophisticated Maya civilization that flourished in this region over a thousand years ago.

name: Santa Catalina Arch
description: Antigua Guatemala is a UNESCO World Heritage site and former capital of Guatemala, famous for its stunning colonial architecture including the iconic Santa Catalina Arch. This distinctive yellow arch, built in the 17th century, once allowed cloistered nuns to pass between convent buildings without entering the street. Today, it stands as one of the most photographed landmarks in Central America, perfectly framing views of the Agua Volcano beyond.

name: Juan Santamaría Statue
description: Alajuela is Costa Rica's second-largest city, home to the statue of Juan Santamaría - the national hero of Costa Rica. This monument honors the young drummer boy who sacrificed his life in 1856 during the Battle of Rivas against William Walker's filibusters. Santamaría has become a symbol of Costa Rican courage and national identity, and the city celebrates him annually on April 11th, a national holiday.

name: Nassau Queen's Staircase
description: Nassau is the capital of the Bahamas, known for its iconic Queen's Staircase - a stunning 66-step stairway carved out of solid limestone by enslaved people in the late 18th century. Named in honor of Queen Victoria, this remarkable monument connects Fort Fincastle to the city below and stands as both a testament to the skill of its builders and a poignant reminder of the islands' colonial history.

name: Port-au-Prince Iron Market
description: Port-au-Prince is the capital and largest city of Haiti, home to the iconic Iron Market (Marché en Fer) - a striking 19th-century iron structure with distinctive red pavilion roofs. Originally prefabricated in France and shipped to Haiti, this beloved market has been the heart of Haitian commerce and culture for over a century, selling everything from local crafts to fresh produce beneath its ornate iron framework.

name: Saint John's Cathedral
description: Saint John's is the capital of Antigua and Barbuda, dominated by the magnificent St. John's Cathedral with its iconic twin-tower baroque façade. Originally built in 1681 and reconstructed after earthquakes, the cathedral's striking white towers rise majestically against the Caribbean sky, serving as the most recognizable landmark of the island nation and a symbol of its Anglican heritage and colonial past.
